FacilityName: City of Lawton Wastewater Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Lawton owns and operates a Wastewater Treatment Plant that uses/stores chlorine (CL2) gas as a disinfectant in its plant discharge before it is discharged into Nine Mile Creek.  The concentrated form of this disinfection agent, before it is mixed with water, can be extremely hazardous if a sudden release/ spill of a 1-ton container occur.  Chlorine gas is stored both inside and outside of the Chlorine Building #43 out of direct sunlight with overhead protection.  The WWTP also uses Sulfur Dioxide for removal of chlorine from the effluent prior to discharge into Nine Mile Creek.  The Sulfur Dioxide is stored both inside and outside of building #47.  The Risk Management Plan (RMP) describes the chemical hazards of chlorine (CL2) and sulfur dioxide gas and explains what the Lawton WWTP is doing to prevent an accidental release/ spill.  This plan has been developed and implemented in accordance with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Accidental Release Prevention Provisions regulations (40 CFR 68) and guidelines.  

The following regulated substance at the Lawton Wastewater Treatment Plant is stored in quantities above the applicable EPA RMP threshold quantity:

SOURCE NAME CHEMICAL City of Lawton WWTP BUILDING 43
CHEMICAL NAME: CHLORINE
CAS NUMBER:  7782-50-5
MAXIMUM NVENTORY QUANTITY (IN POUNDS):  28,000

SOURCE NAME CHEMICAL City of Lawton WWTP BUILDING 47
CHEMICAL NAME: SULFUR DIOXIDE
CAS NUMBER:  7446-06-5
MAXIMUM NVENTORY QUANTITY (IN POUNDS):  24,000

The Lawton WWTP currently has two stationary sources subject to EPA RMP regulations.  The WWTP chlorine feeder room consists of chlorinators that inject chlorine (CL2) gas into its final discharge, for disinfection, before it is discharged into Nine Mile Creek.  The chlorine feeder room is equipped with a ventilation system that, under normal operations, is on standby.  A chlorine detector monitors the air within the room for chlorine gas.  In the event that the concentration of chlorine (CL

2) gas exceeds 1 part per million (ppm), the ventilation system is manually turned on to carry the chlorine from the room through the roof vent.  The feeder room as well as 1-ton container storage/ usage room is heated for temperature control.  The feeders and containers are housed under one roof, with concrete block walls to protect from the sun and elements.  The 1-ton containers are placed on wooden chocks mounted to the concrete floor this prevents rolling of containers.  The Chlorine 1-ton Container Storage/ usage Building, (building #43) is used to store up to (12) twelve 1-ton containers, normally (10) ten are kept on hand with  at least one (1) being hooked-up all the time.  Two (2) are in use, two (2) are in standby/ ready to use as other two (2) empty. These 1-ton containers may be all full at any given time.  The containers are hooked-up to a manifold toward the north end of building #43, in the middle of the building.  The chlorinators/ feeders are located in the East side room of building #43, with entrance from the East side door.  The 1-ton containers on the inside of buildings #43 and #47 are maintained at a constant temperature between 60 and 80 degrees F by a ventilation/heating system.

The temperature of the chlorination/dechlorination system area (feeders, containers that are hooked up and in use or in standby mode) should never reach the critical temperature for CL2 or SO2 gas (290 degrees F).  However, at these temperatures chlorine and or sulfur dioxide will only exist in a gaseous phase.
 
Because the WWTP does not meet the criteria for the Process Safety Management (29 CFR 1910.119) it becomes mandatory to manage the process under Program 2 requirements of the Accidental Release Prevention Provisions.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Lawton is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards.  Lawton outlines the appropriate responses

to releases of hazardous chemical in the Emergency Response Plan (ERP/EPP).  The ERP outlines activities and programs which eliminate and/or reduce the likelihood of a disaster, programs developed to save lives and minimize damage, actions taken to provide emergency assistance, and the activities which return the facility to normal or improved standards.  Safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response efforts.  

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO    

Dispersion modeling was performed to estimate areas that could be affected by a worst-case chlorine and sulfur dioxide release scenario under the least favorable weather conditions.  Prevention and control measures were no considered in evaluating the worst-case scenario.
According to the RMP guidelines, a worst case scenario would involve a rupture of a full 1-Ton container of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide with a release time of approximately 10 minutes.  The entire content of the container would be released with a release rate of 200 pounds per minute.  As a result of the pressure of the released gas, the building would fail and all 2000 lbs of the gas are released into the environment.  Using data prod\vided above, the air dispersion modeling software calculated a total plume distance for the worst-case scenario of 3.0 miles for Chlorine and of 3.1 miles for Sulfur Dioxide.  The worst-case scenario represents the maximum conceivable impact for a release.  Release reporting databases and industry experience suggest that the worst-case release scenario is so unlikely that it should not be the basis for emergency planning.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

Dispersion modeling was also performed to estimate the effective areas for at least one alternative release scenarios for each regulated substance in a regulated process.  The alternative release scenario is based on a split or the decoupling of a 0.375-inch

connector between the cylinder and header, resulting in the release of 317 pounds of chlorine gas over a 60-mnute period.  If the building is assumed to fail (as a result of buildup of internal pressure), the distance to the toxic endpoint (plume distance) was estimated to be approximately 0.10 miles (176 yards) downwind of the WWTP.

The most effective reduction in any risk to the community is achieved by focusing emergency planning on responding to the alternative release scenarios. 

TRAINING

Well-trained operators/maintenance operators are integral to prevention and mitigation of the effects of accidental releases/spills of hazardous chemicals.

The City of Lawton, Assistant Director of Public Works and the RMP team are responsible for maintaining the written Employee Training Program and associated training material and training records.  The WWTP Superintendent is responsible for ensuring that all personnel involved in the handling of Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide at the WWTP complete and maintain all training requirements for his or her position, and that all supporting documentation is filed.  The WWTP Superintendent plans classroom training for all personnel and periodically reviews training records to insure that all employees receive the required training.  

The City of Lawton WTP encourages employee participation and input in maintaining a safe work environment though an Employee Participation Plan.  All new employees will be trained in Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide handling safety, alone with any updates to (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures.  The City of Lawton WWTP Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide Manuals and RMP will be used as the primary guidance during training.  We emphasize health and safety hazards associated with the Hazardous Chemicals involved SOPs and relevant safe work practices.

Initial training for new operators will include both classroom and on-the-job, hands-on training.  New employees to the WWTP are shown the process of maintenance and equipme

nt testing by trained personnel using demonstration and hands-on methods.

All personnel are instructed that repairs and\or replacements are from the original manufacturers and no retrofitting occurs.  All current and new personnel will receive initial program training prior to commencing work.  Topics to be covered during initial training include the following:

?Overview of RMProgram (RMP) describing all elements.

?The Chlorine/.Sulfur Dioxide process operation and hazards associated with these hazardous chemicals/operations.

?Employee Participation Procedure with emphasis on employee rights and on procedures to obtain access to program information.

?Employee involvement in PHAs (Process Hazard Analysis) and right-to-access RMP information, and documenting employee participation.

?MSDS location, Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide Manuals, and SOPs.

?Compliance Audits performed at least every 3 years by WWTP personnel at/on the regulated process areas.

These suit-ups will help determine which WWTP personnel can be relied upon during a real release/leak of Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide gas.  When possible operators/maintenance personnel are enrolled in HAZWOPPER or related courses given by the Red River VoTech and the City of Lawton, (usually yearly).

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The WWTP has an emergency response program that includes an emergency response plan addressing the two EPA RMP-regulated substances managed at the facility.  The emergency response plan contains the following:  

?Procedures for informing the Lawton Fire Department and the community about accidental releases.
?Proper first-aid and emergency response to either stop the release and/or evacuate people who could be affected.

This plan is subject to the following regulatory requirements:

?OSHA 1910.38 (Emergency Action Plan)
?OSHA 1910.120 (HAZWOPER)
?Clean Water Act/SPCC
?RCRA (Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 40 CFR Section 264)
?EPCRA (Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-know Act)

The Em

ergency Response Program includes the necessary response equipment, personnel and training to respond to potential releases.  Procedures for emergency equipment use, inspection, testing, and maintenance have been created.

The City of Lawton, WWTP RMP team is responsible for reviewing and updating the EPP annually.  The WWTP Superintendent is responsible for ensuring that updated copies are distributed to the appropriate locations throughout the City of Lawton.

In the event of an accidental release/leak of Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide gas at the WWTP usage/storage area, WWTP employees are capable of responding in a timely and organized manner.  Employees that live close to the WWTP will be utilized in the response if needed.

LEAK DETECTION PROCEDURES

The WWTP Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide storage/usage areas have leak detection equipment in place.  The alarm system is triggered if a concentration of one parts per million (ppm) of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide gas is detected inside the chemical usage/storage area.  If triggered, a siren and red lights are activated outside the chemical usage/storage area/room.  If the alarm is legitimate, the employee should immediately return to the Administration Building and follow the notification procedures.

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Under the RMP regulations, an accidental release is defined as a release of a regulated substance that ?resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in-place, property damage or environmental damage.?  Within the past 5 years, Lawton has not had any accidental releases.  

COMPLIANCE AUDITS

The City of Lawton WWTP will perform audits to self evaluate the design and effectiveness of its RMProgram and compliance with EPA RMP regulations.  Whenever necessary, recommendations will be developed from the audit to address program deficiencies,  Complaince audits must be performed at least every 3 years at the regulated process area

s at the City of Lawton WWTP.

PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS 

A PHA has been perforned for all regulated processes at the facility in accordance with 40 CFR 68.67.  The PHA was was performed using the What-if Checklist.  The PHA identified the hazards associated with the regulated substances and process; causees of potential accidental release scenarios; safeguards used to prevent accidental releases; and methods used to detect, monitor, or control accidental releases,  The PHA will be revalidated and updated once every 5 years at a minimum.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The policy of the City of Lawton WWTP is to involve its employees in the development and implementation of the EPA RMProgram elements at the process and storage areas which are subject to risk management regulations,  The City of Lawton involves the employees in the PHAs, and other process safety management program elements.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

Under the EPA RMProgram regulations, three levels of prevention program requirements have been established to match the level of risk of off-site impact.  The City of Lawton WWTP must meet Program 2 which is a default program for any one that does not fit into Program 1 or 3.  The Prevention Program is summarized below.
 1.  Process Safety Information - Up-to-date process safety information is maintained in the front of the Administration Building for use by employees operating the regulated process in accordance with 40 CFR 68.65 and includes the following:
*  MSDSs for chlorine and sulfur dioxide with toxicity information, permissible exposure limits (PELs), physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data.
*  Block process flow diagram of the regulated processes.
*  Process chemistry and maximum inventory of the regulated processes.
*  Consequenses of process deviations (from the process hazards analysis).
*  Regulated process equipment information.
2.  Process Hazards Review - The PHA was performed with the What-if Checklist.

Hazards were reviewed.  Any issues identified during the PHA were documented and resolved in a timely manner,  The PHA will be revalidated and updatedat a minimum of once every five years.  
3.  Operating Procedures -- Detailed and up-to-date process standard operating procedures have been developed nad are maintained for each regulated process in accordance with 40 CFR 68.69.  The SOPs are located in the front of the administration Building, in each process aera and in the SCBA cabinet.  SOPs are reviewed as frequently as necessary to ensure that they remain up-to-date and are certified annually as current and accurate.
4.  Training -- see above section on training.
5.  Maintenance -- Written procedures have been developed to unsure that regulated process equipment is properly maintained, tested and inspected at regular intervals and that such activities are thoroughly documented as required by 40 CFR 68.73.  All maintenance, inspection and testing frequencies are consistent with applicalbe manufacturer's recommendations.  Any deficiencies are dealt with in a timely manner.
6.  Complaince Audits -- See section above on compliance audits.
7.  Incident Investigation -- Specific incident investigation, reporting and documentation procedures have been implemented and are followed in accordance with 40 CFR 68.81 in response to any incident involving a regulated process that did or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  
The oncident investigation procedure is initiated as soon as possible and no later than 48 hours following any incident.  A team is established to investigae and document the incident.  Incident investigation reports are maintained at the facility for a minimum of five years.
